importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This decade saw a 25% population decline, revealing a period of crisis and prompting urgent conservation action.
The past five years have shown a slow but steady population increase, indicating a potential recovery trend under conservation efforts.

keyTakeAways: The North Atlantic right whale population is estimated at 384 individuals, an increase of eight from the previous year.
The population has gained over 7% since 2020, showing signs of slow but sustained recovery.
A key milestone is that four mother whales produced calves this year, with shorter reproductive intervals among established mothers — a sign of improved reproductive health.
Only 11 calves were born, below researchers’ hopes, but the entry of new females into the reproductive pool is positive.
No mortalities were detected this year, and injury rates are lower than in recent years, leading scientists to be cautiously optimistic.
The whales face ongoing threats from ship collisions and fishing gear entanglement.
New management measures in Canada, particularly in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, have played a significant role in protecting the species.
Environmental groups warn that weakening protections under the Marine Mammal Protection Act threatens the species' continued survival.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The North Atlantic right whale population, once on the brink of extinction due to whaling and modern threats like ship strikes and fishing gear entanglement, is showing signs of recovery. Estimated at 384 individuals in 2025 — up from 376 in 2024 — the population has grown by 7% since 2020 after a 25% decline between 2010 and 2020. Scientists, including Philip Hamilton and Heather Pettis from the New England Aquarium and NOAA, attribute the positive trend to sustained conservation efforts, including new management measures in Canada’s Gulf of St. Lawrence. While only 11 calves were born this year, the presence of new reproductive females and fewer injuries suggest improved reproductive health. Despite cautious optimism, environmental groups stress that the species remains vulnerable and that weakening protections under the Marine Mammal Protection Act could jeopardize ongoing recovery.
title: North Atlantic Right Whale Population Shows Signs of Recovery Amid Conservation Efforts
